journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Predicting the spontaneous termination of atrial fibrillation based on Poincare section in the electrocardiogram phase space

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Biomedical Engineering, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Islamic Republic of Iran
2Department of Biomedical Engineering, Amir Kabir University of Technology, Tehran, Islamic Republic of Iran
3School of Medical Sciences, Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran, Islamic Republic of Iran
4Cardiac Electrophysiology Research Center, Rajaie Cardiovascular Medical and Research Center, Tehran University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Islamic Republic of Iran

author-notes.corresp: Saman Parvaneh, Golzare Yekom Street, ADL Boulevard, Mirza Babaie Boulevard, Pounak Square, Tehran, 1476766981, Iran Email: parvaneh@ieee.org

abstract.p: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a commonly encountered cardiac arrhythmia. Predicting the conditions under which AF terminates spontaneously is an important task that would bring great benefit to both patients and clinicians. In this study, a new method was proposed to predict spontaneous AF termination by employing the points of section (POS) coordinates along a Poincare section in the electrocardiogram (ECG) phase space.

The AF Termination Database provided by PhysioNet for the Computers in Cardiology Challenge 2004 was applied in the present study. It includes one training dataset and two testing datasets, A and B. The present investigation was initiated by producing a two-dimensional reconstructed phase space (RPS) of the ECG. Then, a Poincare line was drawn in a direction that included the maximum point distribution in the RPS and also passed through the origin of the RPS coordinate system. Afterward, the coordinates of the RPS trajectory intersections with this Poincare line were extracted to capture the local behavior related to the arrhythmia under investigation. The POS corresponding to atrial activity were selected with regard to the fact that similar ECG morphologies such as P waves, which are corresponding to atrial activity, distribute in a specific region of the RPS. Thirteen features were extracted from the selected intersection points to quantify their distributions. To select the best feature subset, a genetic algorithm (GA), in combination with a support vector machine (SVM), was applied to the training dataset. Based on the selected features and trained SVM, the performance of the proposed method was evaluated using the testing datasets.

The results showed that 86.67% of dataset A and 80% of dataset B were correctly classified. This classification accuracy is in the same range as or higher than that of recent studies in this area. These results show that the proposed method, in which no complicated QRST cancelation algorithm was used, has the potential to predict AF termination.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most frequent arrhythmia in clinical practice, with a prevalence of 0.4% in the general population.1 The risk of AF increases with age, from 0.1% among individuals younger than 55 years to 9.0% in persons 80 years of age or older.2 There is an association between the risk of sustained AF and stroke, myocardial infarction, fatigue, dyspnea, palpitations, and heart failure.3,4 AF embolic complications cause ischemic strokes in up to 20 – 25% of cases.5 Furthermore, antiarrhythmic drugs, device therapy, and curative ablation as AF treatments are mostly applied on a trial-and-error basis because existing tests cannot predict the natural history of the arrhythmia and its response to treatments.6,7 Moreover, current AF management guidelines neglect various AF mechanisms and patterns when offering treatment recommendations.8 Therefore, the development of methods that can quantify AF disease states and guide clinicians in AF management is desirable.9
AF is classified into different forms:10

list-item.p: new-onset AF (which refers to the first AF episode detected);
paroxysmal AF (i.e. AF that is self-terminating within 7 days);
persistent AF (interventions are required for termination);
permanent AF (sinus rhythm cannot be restored or maintained).

sec.p: Research shows that 18% of paroxysmal AF cases evolve into permanent AF within 4 years.11 Thus study of paroxysmal AF and prediction of its termination, spontaneous termination, or being sustained, is important. The present study was performed to gain a better pathophysiological understanding of arrhythmia and design quantified rules to evaluate AF treatment methods. Furthermore, the development of a prediction method for the spontaneous termination of paroxysmal AF would make it possible to avoid unnecessary medications and minimize health risks. At the same time, predicting AF sustainability would allow more effective medication to be administered to terminate the arrhythmia.

The AF termination prediction challenge was an open competition designed by the Computers in Cardiology organization in cooperation with PhysioNet in 2004.12,13 This challenge involved the development of automated algorithms for predicting the spontaneous termination of AF. A variety of methods have been proposed for this, including methods that use the electrocardiogram (ECG),6,7,14–29 RR intervals,30,31 and their combination.32–37 Most of the methods based on the ECG have utilized QRST cancelation algorithms in order to extract the atrial activity (AA) as a residual signal. However, because the amplitude of AA is lower than that of ventricular activity (VA) and VA is superimposed on AA in all of the leads, perfect QRS cancelation is not possible.

Frequency and time-frequency features of AA have been employed in most ECG-based research while a small number of methods are based on nonlinear methods. Utilizing features such as the Lyapunov exponent and correlation dimension in AF analysis38,39 can provide global information about the structure of the reconstructed phase space (RPS) and its trajectories; however, these are unable to characterize the shape details of trajectories.40,41

Studies of the geometric patterns of points located on a Poincare surface have provided valuable information in the classification of oceanic signals40,41 and the prediction of AF termination.25 These methods can also be employed in order to capture the detailed information contained in the RPS. All of the aforementioned studies have focused on the use of high-dimensional phase space in order to quantify the geometric patterns of points of section (POS) along a Poincare section. Yang proposed further in-depth investigations in this new framework41 and Sun and Wang suggested introducing new features for multivariate prediction of AF.25

In the present study, we hypothesized that the analysis and quantification of these points in phase space with lower dimension, and from a different point of view which analyzes mostly the distribution of POS along the Poincare line, could be useful. Thus, the aim of this research was predicting the spontaneous termination of AF based on the POS coordinates located on a Poincare section in the RPS of ECG signals.

To overcome the limitation of VA filtering, the fact that each region of the RPS is occupied by similar ECG morphologies was used.42 Therefore, the phase space of the total ECG, without any cancelation, was reconstructed and the POS located in the region related to AA were selected. Afterwards, numerical, statistical, and distribution-based features were used to capture the detailed structure of the AA POS coordinates in the ECG phase space. The proposed method achieved a classification accuracy in the same range as or higher than that in the above-mentioned methods in the prediction of AF spontaneous termination.

sec.title: Database and pre-processing
sec.p: A database (AFTDB) was provided by PhysioNet43 for the Computers in Cardiology Challenge 2004.12,13 It consisted of 80 two-channel ECG recordings (a sampling rate of 128 Hz, 16 bits/sample, and 5 mV resolution). Three AF types with different termination properties are included in this database:

list-item.p: N-AF (label for non-terminating AF). AF episode continues for at least 1 hour after the end of the recording.
S-AF (label for soon-terminating AF). AF episode terminates within 1 min after the end of the recording.
T-AF (label for immediately-terminating AF). AF episode terminates within 1 second after the end of the recording.

sec.p: Each recording is a 1-min segment extracted from a 20–24-h Holter recording from a patient with paroxysmal AF.

The database is divided into a training dataset and two test datasets (A and B). There are 10 recordings for each type in the training dataset (a total of 30 recordings). Test set A contains 30 recordings, with approximately half of them labeled N-AF and the other half T-AF. Test set B contains 10 T-AF recordings and 10 S-AF recordings (20 records). There were two events defined based on this database:

list-item.p: Event 1. The aim of this event was the separation of the N-AF group from the T-AF group, based on the training set and test dataset A.
Event 2. The goal of this event was the use of the training dataset and test dataset B for the classification of T-AF from S-AF.

sec.p: At the time of the challenge the labels of the recordings in the test datasets were neglected, but they later became available for further investigations.
In the present study, all of the records in the database were pre-processed using a single stage of median filtering to reduce the low-frequency baseline wander and drift.44,45

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: In the present study, the spontaneous termination of AF was studied based on intersections of the ECG phase space trajectory with the Poincare surface, from a nonlinear point of view. Figure 1 shows a general block diagram of the proposed method for AF termination prediction.

caption.p: Block diagram of proposed method for AF termination prediction.

sec.title: Electrocardiogram phase space reconstruction
sec.p: The time-delay embedding method is a standard way to reconstruct an attractor from a sequence of scalar measurements. It was initially adopted by Takens.46 This method was used by Richter and Schreiber in the embedding of ECG data and its efficiency for ECG analysis in RPS was proved.47

If the ECG signal is represented by scalar values
s
i
( i = 1 , 2 , … , N )
in a sampled time domain, the delayed vector in a multidimensional phase space can be constructed as follows

where
X ( k )
denotes the delayed vector. The trajectory matrix is obtained as

where
X ( k )
is one point of the trajectory in the phase space, d is the embedding dimension, and τ is the embedding delay. There are several methods for estimating d and τ, whose detailed explanations were provided by Small.48 To calculate the delay, the fact that the outer trajectories, exterior loops, in the RPS correspond to the QRS complex was considered.49 Small delay values do not allow these loops to expand, and they distribute around the y = x line. Moreover, very large values cause these loops to overlap each other. Thus, well-structured trajectories in the RPS are not available. Therefore, we used the area enclosed by the outer loops, Aloops, as a criterion for choosing an appropriate embedding delay, or reconstruction lag. The procedure for this method was as below:

p.italic: Increase the reconstruction lag from an initial value equal to one (τ
1) until the first local maximum of Aloops is reached (where Aloops becomes maximum for the first time and will decline with a further increase in delay).

sec.p: The mean value of delay found by applying the above method on the training dataset was selected as the embedding delay. The value of the reconstruction lag obtained for our database was two (corresponding to an embedding delay equal to 15.6 ms).

The embedding dimension, d, was chosen equal to two, because this dimension empirically appears to be almost sufficient in producing the ECG attractor. Here, by employing the false-nearest neighbor (FNN) algorithm50 on the same training dataset, it has been found that the dimension two can reproduce the RPS. This result re-emphasizes the empirical results obtained previously. It should be noted that a clear phase space trajectory can be represented in two-dimensional RPS.

To compare the Poincare sections of different signals, they should have a unique framework. Therefore, prior to any further processing, a normalized RPS was obtained. The shape of the phase space was preserved in this new space, with the differences consisting merely of differences in the scales of the coordinate axes. A normalized trajectory matrix was obtained by dividing each element of X by smax where
and Xnormalized can be represented as
Thus, the phase space of the normalized trajectory matrix spans from –1 to +1.

Lead II of the 2 second segment from terminating AF record number four (t04) and its corresponding RPS are shown in Figure 2(a) and (b). Red dots in Figure 2(b) are available data samples, and blue lines show the reconstructed trajectory.

caption.p: The step-by-step procedure for extracting POS corresponding to AA. (a) Lead II of the 2-s segment from terminating AF record number four (t04). (b) RPS corresponds to ECG shown in (a) with embedding lag equal to two. (c) The direction that includes maximum point distribution in the RPS and also passes through the origin of the RPS coordinate system is shown with the straight red line. Its angle from the horizontal axis is 45°. (d) Poincare line is shown with the straight black line and POS intersecting with the Poincare line are shown with green dots, revealing that POS correspond to AA and VA together. (e) POS located in AA region are shown with green dots.

sec.title: Poincare section and Poincare hyperplane
sec.p: A Poincare section can indicate the type of attractor and reveal the shape specifications of the original trajectory.41 The first step in constructing a Poincare section is Poincare hyperplane selection. After that, the Poincare sections are the intersection points of the hyperplane and trajectory. The POS are defined as the points at which the trajectory passes through a Poincare plane in a defined direction. By studying the Poincare section of the RPS instead of the RPS itself, the complexity of the phase space representation is reduced by at least one Euclidean dimension, from N-dimensional to (N – 1)-dimensional. With this dimension reduction, the geometric complexity of the state space trajectory will decrease considerably.51

The goal of the Poincare section is to find some kind of structure in the attractor and reveal much useful information about the internal structure of the attractor. This information is not visible in the RPS domain. Furthermore, it could provide us with the following benefits:

list-item.p: the pattern of Poincare section might indicate the type of attractor;
it simplifies the study of the RPS because of its fewer Euclidean dimensions than the RPS;
the Poincare section reduces the quantity of data for analysis, this reduction leads to less computation time which is useful for online analysis and prediction.

sec.p: In the present study, an embedding dimension equal to two was chosen (see subsection on Electrocardiogram phase space reconstruction), which led to a Poincare line as
where its position is defined by slope m and intercept b.

There is no well-known method for determining Poincare plane coordinates. Finding a good section that does not lead to a small number of intersection points requires some experimentation, and as Kantz and Schreiber state, the choice of a proper surface is a critical step in data analysis.52 A number of studies assumed that the Poincare plane is perpendicular to one of the RPS axes and used the correct classification rate as a criterion to select coordinates of the Poincare plane along that axis, adopting Poincare planes that resulted in the minimum classification error.25,40,41

In the proposed method, the following rules were defined to determine the Poincare line. The Poincare line was drawn in a way that it passed through the two following points in the two-dimensional RPS:

list-item.p: The origin of the RPS (0,0), which corresponded to the signal baseline in the time domain.

(
x
opt
,
y
opt
) with the direction at which the distribution of Poincare section points was the maximum and the distance of the intersection point from the origin of the RPS as a reference point was the highest possible value.

sec.p: In our investigation, it was empirically seen that an important part of the information was located in the direction with the largest variance.
Based on the above definitions, m and b can be found as
and

Applying the training dataset, the direction with the highest variance was recognized to have an angle of 45° with the horizontal axis. This direction for t04 record is shown as a red line in Figure 2(c). Each POS in this direction corresponded with one of the following points in the time domain:

list-item.p: A point around the ECG extremum, maximum or minimum.

A point around the ECG baseline. In AF, physiologically, the fibrillatory waves substituted for the P wave and there are more variations around this line. Thus, this case is of vital importance for our purpose because the points around the baseline were mainly affected by AF.

sec.p: The method explained in the subsection Selecting points of section related to atrial activity was used to choose the POS corresponding to the second category.

Figure 3 shows a sample phase space with six points, in which the numbers above the filled circles indicate the occurrence sequence of points. In Figure 3, the points are connected by a solid line in order to reconstruct the phase space trajectory, and the dashed line is an assumed Poincare line for illustration purposes.

caption.p: Sample figure to illustrate the definition of exact and interpolated intersection with Poincare line.

sec.p: As can be seen in Figure 3, point 2 is an exact intersection from the left to right direction. Moreover, there is an intersection with the Poincare line in the same direction when the trajectory goes from point 5 to point 6. Therefore, there is a POS in this condition that should be found by interpolation; this point will be an interpolated intersection.

In Figure 4, the origin of the RPS was selected as the reference point and the distances between intersection points and this reference point were calculated, where L1 and L2 represent the distances between the first and second intersections with the Poincare line and the reference point. sec.p: In equation (15), a positive Lm corresponds to a Poincare intersection on the right side of the reference point and vice versa. From here, we assume that POS distances from the RPS origin can be denoted as
We call this an intersection information series (IIS), where ntotal is the number of intersections with the Poincare line. The POS for t04 record is shown in Figure 2(d).

sec.title: Selecting points of section related to atrial activity
sec.p: Because the POS found in the previous subsection capture information about both the atrial and ventricular activity of the heart, we needed to select the intersections that correspond to AA. For this purpose, just the POS in a special part of the RPS corresponding to AA were kept. It was found that intersections located in the region of the RPS defined below provided us with superior information related to AA
Therefore, just the POS located in this region were selected for further investigations. In the next subsection, the number of intersections in the AA region will be denoted by nAA.
POS corresponding to AA for t04 record are shown in Figure 2(e). Distances of these POS along the Poincare line with their corresponding intersection sequence are displayed in Figure 5.

caption.p: POS distances in AA region calculated from Figure 2(e). Each filled circle shows the intersection with the Poincare line and the number above the filled circle shows the intersection sequence in the AA region.

sec.title: Feature extraction from series that quantify intersection with Poincare line
sec.p: Intuitively, the geometric patterns of the points on the phase space and their distribution carry useful information about the local behavior in the RPS. The features that can quantify this information are limited.41 We have grouped our features into three main categories:

list-item.p: numerical features;
statistical features;
distribution-based features.

sec.title: Numerical features
sec.p:
In the analysis of an ECG Poincare section, it is observed that
n
observable
≤
n
total
, where ntotal denotes the number of intersections found in the subsection Points of section coordinates and nobservable expresses the visually observable intersections in the RPS. This observation implies multiple intersections with a special point on the Poincare line. This explanation leads to the use of the numerical features below:

list-item.p: Total number of intersections (ntotal). This is the number of points found by the algorithm explained in the subsection Points of section coordinates.

Number of observable intersections (nobservable). This can be found by eliminating multiple intersections with the special point on the Poincare line. After the removal of the same Lm in IIS, the number of remaining distances is nobservable.

sec.title: Statistical features
sec.p: Statistical features such as the mean, range, standard deviation, coefficient of the variation (CV), Kth percentile, and interquartile range (IQR) were calculated for the series extracted in the previous step, IIS in the AA region. Subsequently, their definitions will be reviewed in this subsection.

If Li denotes a series of values where
i = 1 , 2 , … ,
n
AA
, the mean value determines the point that the series is distributed around. It is calculated as follows
The range determines the interval at which the information series has value and is found using the following equation
Lmax and Lmin are the maximum and minimum values of Li, respectively. Usage of IISrange is limited because it depends on two extreme values.
The standard deviation of a union is the square root of the variance and is obtained through the following equation
This quantifies the dispersion of the series under study around the mean value.
CV is defined as the standard deviation divided by the mean
It is used to standardize the variation in a way that allows us to compare two numerical distributions measured on different scales.
The Kth percentile represents a value at which K% of the series values are less than or equal to it. The 25th, 50th, and 75th percentiles were calculated in our analysis.

The IQR is the difference between the first quartile (25th percentile) and third quartile (75th percentile). Actually, it contains the middle 50% of the distribution and is unaffected by extreme values.

sec.title: Distribution-based features
sec.p:
A histogram is a bar chart useful for analyzing the distribution of a series containing quantitative data.53 It is a graphical tool that can be generated from data by dividing its range, through Lmin to Lmax, into J bins and counting the number of data points in each bin. Thus, a histogram of data is a discrete function,
h (
r
j
) =
n
j
, where rj is the jth bin and nj is the number of data points located in it. If we normalize the histogram as below, it will be relative frequency histogram which is the most commonly used histogram54

where
f (
r
j
)
is the percentage of the sample observations falling in bin j and n is the total number of points included in a histogram. It is valuable in comparison of frequency distributions of two datasets with different data points.55 Because the shape of a histogram is sensitive to the number of bins, the optimal number of histogram bins should be selected. The method used by Shimazaki and Shinomoto was used for selecting bin numbers by considering the data.56 This value provides the most efficient and unbiased estimation of the histogram. The bin numbers were equal to 12, with the average value of bin numbers for the training dataset determined by the Shimizaki and Shinomoto method and used in this study.

The shape differences between histograms of IIS, generated based on distances in the AA region for three records of different termination types, are shown in Figure 6. These differences motivated us to obtain features that could describe the dissimilarity numerically. In order to quantify the shape difference available in the AF histograms with different termination conditions, the skewness, kurtosis, and entropy of IIS were utilized.

sec.p: We define the Kth central moment of a distribution as below
where μ is the mean value, given by
The skewness and kurtosis are the normalized third and fourth moments of the given series distribution. The skewness represents the asymmetry of the distribution and can be calculated as below
The kurtosis describes the peakedness of the distribution and is related to the presence of a long tail in the histogram. The following equation is used to derive the kurtosis
In equations (25) and (26), m2 is the variance.
Entropy is a measure used to delineate the spread of a distribution and is defined as below
It is the maximum for uniform distributions, and its value is lower for distributions with narrow ranges of significant frequency values.
The definition of extracted features is given in Table 1.

sec.title: Feature selection and classification of atrial fibrillation termination by genetic algorithm/support vector machine
sec.p: The analysis of the data led to 13 features in the present study, including numerical, statistical, and distribution-based features. In prediction and classification problems, using all of the features does not necessarily lead to the best result. Thus, finding a subset of features for the data that is useful in solving the main problem is crucial. This task is known as feature selection. It also provides a better understanding of the data by finding important features and the way they are related to each other in a special classification task.

The wrapper approach, in which the selection task is performed simultaneously with the classification process, was adopted as the feature selection method. In this method, the quality of a candidate subset is evaluated by the correct classification rate obtained for the training dataset. Classifier training for each candidate subset makes the wrapper method computationally intensive. To reduce the feature selection time, an evolutionary algorithm such as the genetic algorithm (GA) may be utilized to explore the space of possible feature subsets.57

The main procedure in the current study consisted of evaluating the efficiency of a feature subset using a support vector machine (SVM) classifier and using a GA to determine the best subset of features based on the SVM classification rate.58,59

sec.title: Genetic algorithm
sec.p: The effectiveness of GA in a rapid global search of large spaces made it suitable for our feature selection task. In this subsection, the important features of GA are briefly mentioned

list-item.p: Chromosome and initial population. A chromosome is a string of genes. Each gene refers to one of the available features. One and zero values for each gene show that the corresponding feature is included or not included, respectively. Thus, each chromosome represents a gene subset and its length is equal to the number of features. In this research, the initial population of the GA was randomly generated according to a uniform distribution.
Fitness function. The fitness of a feature subset, i.e. chromosome, is assessed by the classification rate of an SVM classifier on the training dataset.

Mutation and crossover. Mutation and crossover are two of the most widely used operators for a GA. A bit of a single string generally changes by the mutation operator. Crossover operates on two parent strings to generate two offspring. In this research, the scattered crossover and Gaussian mutation operators were used.
Stopping criterion. Reaching a predefined number of generations, StallGenLimit, or obtaining a fitness value of 100% was selected as the end state of an evolution process.

sec.title: Support vector machine classifier
sec.p: SVMs are basically binary classification algorithms. Their basic idea is to find a separating hyperplane with the maximal margin. For linearly separable data, the hyperplane is computed directly. However, for nonlinearly separable data, the data samples are mapped to a higher dimensional space where such a separating hyperplane can be found. The kernel function defines the mapping mechanism. The capability of SVM in pattern classification problems with a limited number of samples encouraged us to use it as a classifier. Given training set pairs for a binary classification problem as

on which
x

sec.p: Here, γ, r, and d are kernel parameters that should be defined and tuned by the user.

sec.title: Analysis criteria
sec.p: An analysis of the defined features and their capability in AF termination prediction were assessed from two different perspectives:

list-item.p: Statistical viewpoint. The mean and standard deviation of each feature were reported. Furthermore, the Mann–Whitney test was used to test whether or not two samples came from the same distribution. In the statistical feature analysis, a p-value of 0.05 was considered as the level of significance. Thus, p-values under 0.05 showed that the associated feature was significantly different among the various classes.
Classification standpoint. The accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity of three common measures in classification analysis were used in this study. They are calculated as follows
The definitions of TP, TN, FP, and FN based on the AF termination prediction task are summarized in Table 2.

caption.p: Definitions of TP, TN, FP, and FN based on prediction of AF termination.

sec.title: Features analysis
sec.p: The features defined in this paper were recognized as being correlated with each other using a Spearman rank correlation method. In the analysis of the correlation matrix, correlation coefficient values that were between 0.9 and 1.0 meant that features were very highly correlated and correlation coefficients whose magnitudes were between 0.8 and 0.9 showed high correlation among features. The matrix of correlation between N-AF and T-AF in the training data set showed four highly correlated groups of features: IISstd and IISrange (0.883), IISstd and IISIQR (0.821), IISIQR and IISpr75 (0.809), IISkurt and IISent (− 0.869).

The correlation coefficient values between the S-AF and T-AF features in the training set showed four very highly correlated groups: IISstd and IISIQR (0.952), IISstd and IISpr75 (0.922), IISIQR and IISpr75 (0.949), and IISkurt and IISent (− 0.919). Also, there was one highly correlated group in this case: IISrange and IISIQR (0.835).

The mean and standard deviations of the 13 features for the N-AF, S-AF, and T-AF classes in the training set are shown in Table 3. The ability of these features to discriminate between N-AF and T-AF, and between T-AF and S-AF, is reported in Table 3; this evaluation was performed using a Mann–Whitney test. As shown in Table 3,IISkurt is the best feature for discriminating between N-AF and T-AF (p = 0.002). In addition, the p-values of IISpr75, IISent, IISIQR, IISpr50, IISstd, IISCV, and IISrange between N-AF and T-AF were smaller than 0.05. This confirmed that these two different AF termination conditions may be statistically differentiated by using the above-mentioned features.

caption.p: Statistical analysis of 13 extracted features in prediction of spontaneously terminating AF. Significant p-values are highlighted.

sec.p: IISpr50 with a p-value of 0.275 was the most efficient feature in discriminating between T-AF and S-AF, and none of the p-values in the T/S episodes were less than 0.05. Therefore, we conclude that there was not sufficient statistical evidence to differentiate between T-AF and S-AF.
By studying the ECG amplitudes around the baseline, the following results have been found which are related to pathophysiological aspects of arrhythmia:

list-item.p: T-AF’s ECG has lower variations around the baseline than N-AF’s ECG; it corresponds to a lower value for IISstd and IISCV for T-AF. This shows that there exist higher-frequency drivers which create fibrillatory conduction in the atria in long-standing AFs (N-AF).60

F-wave amplitudes for N-AF are mostly small values; however, for T-AF larger values in amplitude have been found. This condition leads to larger values for POS distances located in AA region for T-AF and is corresponding to larger values for IISIQR, IISpr50, IISpr75, and IISkurt. This result conforms to an association between F-wave amplitude and AF recurrence, obtained in research by Nault et al.61 This condition is caused by atrophy of atrial muscle in long-standing AF (N-AF).

sec.title: Feature selection and prediction performance
sec.p: Because there were 13 features for our classification task, feature selection was carried out to obtain a low-dimension classifier. For this task, the GA seeks the best feature subset which satisfies the stopping criterion. The fitness function in each step is the classification rate of the SVM classifier which has been trained by the available training dataset and the feature subset selected by GA. After the feature selection step, the number of ones in the final chromosome defines the best number of features, and their corresponding indices define the best features. For further investigation, the SVM trained by the best feature subset was used, and classification accuracy for the test dataset was calculated.

The existence of different kernels in an SVM classifier made its selection an important task. In our study, an order two polynomial was chosen as the kernel. In addition, linear and RBF kernels were utilized, but the results obtained with these kernels were not satisfactory. The parameters utilized for the GA and SVM are presented in Table 4.

tr.td: Method for finding the separating hyperplane

sec.p: A subset with six features, IISmean, IISstd, IISrange, IISIQR, IISskew, and IISent, results in the best prediction performance in event 1. The classification results based on these features for the training dataset and test dataset A, N/T-type episodes, are shown in Table 5. A total correct classification percentage of 92% (46/50) was achieved by using these features. The classification accuracy for testing dataset A was 86.67% (26/30).

caption.p: N/T-AF classification results for best feature subset in training data set and testing dataset A.

sec.p: The T/S-type AF classification results for the feature subset IISpr25, IISpr50, IISpr75, ntotal, and nobservable in the training dataset and testing dataset B are given in Table 6. The overall classification accuracy in this task was 36/40 (90%). Furthermore, a correct classification rate of 80% (16 /20) was achieved in test dataset B.

caption.p: T/S-AF classification results for best feature subset in training dataset and testing dataset B.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The AF termination prediction set by the Computers in Cardiology Challenge 2004 and the database release by PhysioNet12,13,43 motivated much research in this field.6,7,14–37 The next paragraphs provide a brief review of these research works and their methodologies. A comparison of their results with the accuracy of our method is reported in Table 7.

caption.p: Comparison of our results with other research.

fn.p: N/A: not available; NP: not performed.

sec.p: Overall and 1-second peak frequencies were considered by Petrutiu et al.14 Mora and colleagues applied the fibrillatory wave spectrum and calculated the main and second peak frequencies, bandwidth, and spectral concentration. Furthermore, they utilized the instantaneous main frequency, instantaneous second frequency, and number of secondary peaks obtained by a time-frequency analysis.15 The peak frequency was calculated by Xi and Shkurovich.16 Nilsson et al. used the fibrillation frequency and exponential decay of the spectral profile.17 In addition, they added three different measures of complexity to their previous features, namely spectral entropy, sample entropy, and fractional spectral radius.6 Zhongchao et al.22 calculated the dominant peak frequency, mean instantaneous frequency, index of stability for the temporal frequency, and mean ventricular rate index. Saberi and colleagues26 extracted the spectral and time-frequency parameters of ECG AA, after canceling the QRST complex. In addition, the mean and standard deviation of the RR and mean of the heart rate were included in their analysis. The dominant AF frequency and mean RR interval were considered in Cantini et al.32 and Hayn et al.33 Lemay et al. extracted 12 features of atrial activity using data derived from the ECG and RR intervals.34 Some of the most important features were the fibrillatory wave peak, average AA amplitude, normalized covariance, and mean RR. Spectral features such as the frequency of the power spectral density peak (fPmaxb), maximum value of the power spectral density (Pdmaxb), 3-dB width of the peak (wb3dB), and power in the 3-dB band around the peak (Pb3dB) were extracted based on AA data obtained from ECG.36

Nine distinct time-frequency distributions of AA sequences were calculated in Vaya et al.20 and the mean approximate entropy of the peak frequency and spectral concentration of these distributions were obtained. A set of linear and nonlinear features was extracted from the ECG signals and their RR interval series such as the fibrillatory frequency, total spectral power, and mean, regularity, and approximated entropy of the RR intervals.35 In Diaz et al.,37 four indices were extracted for the classification of test dataset A, including the atrial fibrillatory frequency (AFF) and the mean, standard deviation, and approximate entropy of the RR intervals. For the classification of testing set B, the AFF and energies of the 3–7 Hz and 7–11 Hz bands for the final 10 seconds and final 5 seconds were used.

Alcaraz et al. used the wavelet sample entropy (WSE) to predict N-AF and T-AF; WSE is the combination of the wavelet transform properties and sample entropy as a regularity measurement index.21 A combination of the fundamental frequency, sample entropy of the time reconstructed scale, and wavelet coefficients vector was used by Alcaraz and Rieta to discriminate between N- and T-type AF.23,24 They later27 used the sample entropy as a nonlinear organization estimator on AA, which was extracted by selective filtering. Alcaraz and Rieta proposed three strategies for reducing the noise and ventricular residues and enhancing the AA main features.28 The sample entropy was utilized for AA organization estimation in each strategy. These strategies were TQ interval organization (TQO) analysis, wavelet transformed organization (WTO) analysis, and selective filtering organization (SFO) analysis. The method proposed by Alcaraz and Rieta29 computed the sample entropy over the AA obtained from TQ segments, which were free of QRST complexes.

Fractal features such as the fractal dimension, mass dimension, and lacunarities were used by Esgiar and Chakravorty.18 Gaussian mixture models of RPS for the last 2 seconds of data were utilized as a nonlinear approach.19 The study by Sun and Wang25 reconstructed a high-dimensional phase space for the ECG AA. Then, points on a given Poincare surface were studied and quantified using the regularity index feature. Sun and Wang also proposed features to quantify the structure of the recurrence plot in order to predict the termination of the AF.7

Logan and Healey modeled RR intervals using Gaussian mixtures.30 Sun and Wang later extracted 11 statistical features of the RR interval and used four features for quantifying the geometric properties of the RR Poincare plot.31

According to Table 7, the accuracy of our proposed method is in the same range as or higher than that in other research. In most of the research that used ECG as a signal for AF termination prediction, the AA was extracted from ECG with complicated QRST cancelation. Unlike these other methodologies, our procedure did not use any conventional QRS cancelation algorithm. Instead, we used the RPS of the total ECG and applied a Poincare section to it. Then, to select POS related to AA, we just used a very simple rule; in this rule, we selected POS in a special region that was related to AA.

The common methods for QRST cancelation are average beat subtraction (ABS),62,63 spatiotemporal QRST cancellation,64 principal component analysis (PCA),65 and independent component analysis (ICA).66 The main differences between our methods and the others are listed below and tabulated in Table 8:

list-item.p: Extraction of AA related to each ECG lead is important in AF prediction and analysis; but both PCA and ICA methods derive a global atrial signal with contributions of all leads. Our method extracts AA related to each ECG lead under consideration.

An adequate computation of an average beat for acceptable QRST cancelation requires a recording which includes a number of cycles. Furthermore, PCA and ICA need a certain period of time to calculate the mixing matrix adequately in order to extract AA. However, in the present study, as soon as the RPS can be reconstructed with availability of two samples, our proposed method can start the POS extraction and selecting those points which are related to AA.
Employing spatial diversity in multi-lead PCA and ICA methods requires a recording with a minimum number of leads whereas our method works with a single lead.

sec.p: In addition and as shown in Table 8, our proposed method has the advantages of the common AA extraction methods.

caption.p: Comparison of different AA extraction methods with our proposed method.

tr.th: Extraction of AA related to lead under consideration
Adequate AA extraction from limited time recording

sec.p: Most studies on AFTDB, the database used in the present research, used ABS for AA extraction from ECG since two leads are available in this database. Multi-lead PCA and ICA methods cannot be used in this database since the number of available leads is limited. Moreover, single-lead PCA needs some single-lead ECG cycles which are not suitable for online analysis of AF.
The benefits of our method can be summarized as:

list-item.p: Extraction of AA from a single lead is useful for analysis of the ECG Holter monitoring. This is critical since two or three leads are monitored in the most of the Holters and minimizing the lead’s number is a promising approach in Holter monitoring, especially for telemonitoring applications.
Using the minimum number of ECG cycles, in comparison with other methods, makes our proposed method a suitable approach for online AA extraction.

sec.p: Besides the rationale mentioned above, our method is free from average beat calculation as in ABS and QRST spatiotemporal cancelation and from finding the mixing matrix as in ICA and PCA methods.

According to our extensive survey in our application area, using ECG amplitude in the shape of average AA amplitude is limited to only one study done by Lemay et al. for which the results are lower than others.34 In the present study we utilized ECG amplitudes and reconstructed its phase space, then defined the features that quantified the POS located in AA region. It has been shown that employing ECG amplitude intersection with the Poincare line in the AA region instead of using the average AA amplitude improves the prediction accuracy (Table 7). This accuracy shows that analysis of ECG amplitude dynamics provides useful information in the form of the distribution of the points along the Poincare section for AF termination prediction. Furthermore, the results of our proposed method can yield pathophysiological understanding about arrhythmia based on ECG amplitude and can provide a new method for prediction of spontaneously terminating AF. In addition, ECG amplitude can be used as complementary factor in AF analysis alongside its frequency and time-frequency analysis.

Most of the features used in the prediction of AF termination that were based on the ECG utilized information from the frequency domain and time-frequency domain. Thus, there have been a limited number of nonlinear studies in which the RPS domain structure was employed, such as in our methodology.7,19,25

Roberts and Povinelli statistically modeled the global structure of RPS, which was reconstructed using AA.19 In addition, Sun and Wang used the recurrence plot in their analysis, which provided global information about the recurrences of states in the ECG phase space.7 Compared with their research, our method attempts to capture the local structure embedded in the RPS of the ECG.

Phase space reconstruction in lower dimensions, equal to two, and reconstruction based on the full ECG rather than just its AA and utilizing new features are the main differences between our work and the research done by Sun and Wang in phase space with embedding dimension equal to 200.25 From a representation perspective, Poincare sections with four or more dimensions are not useful because they cannot be viewed on a monitor or plotted on paper. Visualizing the Poincare section on a monitor or paper can benefit clinicians with a new tool which is complementary to reading the ECG on paper or a monitor. In this work, study of the RPS in dimension two and POS in this dimension can provide a visual tool for clinicians. In addition, Sun and Wang assumed a Poincare hyperplane perpendicular to the RPS axis. They chose a Poincare plane position that resulted in minimum classification errors. Their method for positioning the Poincare hyperplane did not contain any physiological background. In contrast with their method, we placed the Poincare line in a direction where the distribution of points in the RPS was the maximum. Selection of this direction leads to a physiological interpretation, because it provides information about the variation around the baseline. Our features mainly quantify the distribution of the POS while their method interprets the geometric structure of the POS. Based on an extensive survey these well-known features have been used for the first time in the area of POS quantification.

The present results make us believe that a wealth of information is contained in the structure of the ECG RPS. Moreover, the definition of new features, improvement in the criterion used for determining the Poincare line coordinates, and use of a larger database could improve the proposed method.

Furthermore, we hypothesize that by employing ECG extracted features such as ours and combining them with the promising results of using RR in previous studies done by Sun and Wang31 and Diaz et al.,37 a better understanding of underlying mechanisms responsible for spontaneous termination of AF can be gained which leads to an improved prediction. This approach will be investigated in our future works.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The present study utilized a new method to quantify AF dynamics with different termination properties: N-AF, S-AF, and T-AF. Along with the presentation of a new rule for determining the coordinates of a Poincare line which was not perpendicular to the RPS axis as in previous studies,25,40,41 a simple method was used to highlight the Poincare intersection in the region of the RPS related to AA which could be applied to a sample comprising a single lead with a small number of data and capture POS related to AA of the lead under consideration. In addition, different features for quantification of AF termination type, including numerical, statistical, and distribution-based features, were used. The distribution-based features showed that distribution of POS along the Poincare line can be used to differentiate between AF with different termination conditions. In event 1, correct classification rates of 92% and 86.67% were achieved for the total dataset (training dataset and test dataset A) and test dataset A for discriminating between N-AF and T-AF, respectively. The correct classification rates for differentiating between T-AF and S-AF, event 2, were 90% for the total dataset and 80% for training dataset B.

The results of the proposed diagnostic method could provide a suitable curative strategy under conditions where the heart cannot terminate its AF arrhythmia spontaneously, while under other conditions, therapeutic methods and their risks could be avoided. Accordingly, benefits to both patients and clinicians would be achieved.

In conclusion, the presented method for AF termination prediction utilized ECG amplitude in one lead and with minimum number of data samples to analyze its dynamics. Furthermore, the defined features showed that the distribution of intersection points between an ECG’s RPS trajectories and Poincare line was capable of AF termination prediction.
However, further investigations on features that quantify POS and the use of a larger dataset may improve the prediction of spontaneously terminating AF.

sec.title: Abbreviations
sec.p: AA atrial activity

AF atrial fibrillation
AFF atrial fibrillatory frequency
CV coefficient of variation
ECG electrocardiogram
GA genetic algorithm
ICA independent component analysis
IIS intersection information series
IQR interquartile range
N-AF non-terminating AF
PCA principal component analysis
POS point of section
RBF radial basis function
RPS reconstructed phase space
S-AF soon-terminating AF

SS sign sequence
SVM support vector machine
T-AF immediately-terminating AF

VA ventricular activity
